title: Axolotl Feeding Guide: Diet, Schedule & Nutrition
description: Complete feeding guide for axolotls covering age-based schedules, staple foods (earthworms, blackworms, frozen fish), occasional feeders, portion sizes, and foods to avoid.
author: Habitat Builder
excerpt: Evidence-based axolotl diet recommendations including feeding schedules, portion sizes, food safety, and nutritional requirements for Ambystoma mexicanum.

content.heading: Axolotl Feeding Guide
content.text: Axolotls are carnivorous amphibians that use powerful suction feeding to inhale prey whole. Their diet in captivity should mimic the invertebrates, small fish, and aquatic worms they consume in Lake Xochimilco. This guide covers age-appropriate feeding schedules, staple and occasional foods, portion sizing, and common feeding mistakes.
Axolotls do NOT chew. All food must be small enough to swallow whole. Oversized food causes choking, stress, or regurgitation. When in doubt, cut food into smaller pieces.
Feeding frequency changes dramatically as axolotls mature. Overfeeding causes obesity and water quality issues, while underfeeding stunts growth.

rows: As much as they'll eat in 10-15 minutes
Blackworms, daphnia, baby brine shrimp, small earthworm pieces
Once daily or every other day
Earthworms, blackworms, bloodworms, small frozen fish
Large earthworms, nightcrawlers, frozen silversides, occasional variety foods
High-protein foods—earthworms, blackworms, Repashy Grub Pie

items: Juveniles: Rapid growth phase—need frequent, smaller meals to support development
Adults: Slower metabolism—overfeeding causes obesity, fatty liver disease, reduced lifespan
Water Quality: Less frequent feeding = less waste = more stable water parameters
Natural Feeding: Wild axolotls are opportunistic feeders—don't eat daily

content.text: Transition from daily to every-other-day feeding around 6 inches length, then to every 2-3 days at 8+ inches. This mimics natural slowing metabolism and prevents obesity.
These foods provide complete nutrition and should form 80-90% of diet.
Earthworms and nightcrawlers are the GOLD STANDARD for axolotl nutrition.

items: Complete Nutrition: High protein, moderate fat, essential vitamins and minerals
Appropriate Size: Can source small to large worms for any axolotl size
Easy to Digest: Soft-bodied, no hard exoskeleton
Readily Available: Pet stores, bait shops, online suppliers
Long-Term Storage: Live worms store 1-2 months in refrigerator
Red Wigglers (Eisenia fetida): Small, active, ideal for juveniles and smaller adults (4-6 inches)
European Nightcrawlers (Eisenia hortensis): Medium size, excellent for sub-adults and adults (6-10 inches)
Canadian Nightcrawlers (Lumbricus terrestris): Large, best for adult axolotls 8+ inches
Avoid: Wild-caught earthworms (pesticide exposure), bleached/dyed bait worms
Bait Shops: Cheap, readily available—rinse thoroughly before feeding
Pet Stores: "Fishing worms" or "feeder worms"—more expensive but convenient
Online: Uncle Jim's Worm Farm, Amazon, reptile food suppliers—buy in bulk for savings
DIY Worm Composting: Maintain worm bin at home—sustainable, cost-effective long-term
Store in breathable container (plastic tub with air holes)
Use bedding: coconut coir, shredded paper, or worm-specific bedding
Keep refrigerated at 40-50°F—worms go dormant, live 1-2 months
Mist bedding weekly to maintain moisture (not soaking wet)
Remove dead worms immediately to prevent contamination
Feed worms vegetable scraps to "gut-load" before feeding to axolotl
Remove worm from refrigerator 10 minutes before feeding (warms to room temp)
Rinse worm in dechlorinated water
For juveniles: Cut worm into 1-2 inch pieces with clean scissors
For adults: Feed whole worm or cut large nightcrawlers in half
Use feeding tongs to present worm near axolotl's head—encourages natural hunting
Worm will wriggle, triggering axolotl's suction feeding response
Remove uneaten worm pieces after 30 minutes

content.text: Small aquatic worms, excellent for juveniles and variety.

items: High Protein: Excellent nutrition, promotes growth
Small Size: Perfect for juveniles under 4 inches
Live in Tank: Can add to tank, axolotl hunts them (enrichment)
Visible Movement: Wriggling triggers strong feeding response
Expensive: More costly than earthworms per feeding
Short Storage: Live only 1-2 weeks refrigerated
Availability: Not all pet stores stock—often need to order online
Store in shallow dish with 1-2 inches dechlorinated water
Refrigerate at 40-50°F
Change water daily—worms produce waste quickly
Remove dead worms (turn white) immediately
Use within 1-2 weeks for best nutrition
Scoop desired amount with small net or spoon
Drop into tank near axolotl—worms sink slowly, triggering feeding response
For juveniles: feed 10-20 worms per meal
For adults: feed 30-50 worms or supplement with other foods

content.text: Small frozen fish, good protein source for adults.

items: Convenient: Long freezer storage (6+ months)
High Protein: Good muscle meat content
Variety: Different from worm-based diet
Readily Available: Most fish stores stock
Less Nutritious: Frozen process depletes some vitamins
Thiaminase: Some fish contain enzyme that breaks down vitamin B1 (feed variety)
Water Quality: Oily—clouds water, increases waste more than worms
Silversides: Small saltwater fish, 2-4 inches—ideal size for adults
Frozen Brine Shrimp: Tiny, good for juveniles (less nutritious than blackworms)
Frozen Bloodworms: Small, good supplemental food (not sole diet)
Thaw fish in small dish of tank water (10-15 minutes)
Feed 1-2 silversides to adult axolotl as meal
Use feeding tongs to present near axolotl
Remove uneaten fish after 30 minutes—decomposes quickly, pollutes water

content.text: Powdered gel diet formulated for amphibians.

items: Complete Nutrition: Vitamin/mineral fortified
Long Shelf Life: Powder stores 1+ years
Convenient: Mix with boiling water, sets into gel
Portion Control: Easy to cut into exact sizes
Less Palatable: Some axolotls refuse—not as enticing as live worms
Learning Curve: Axolotls need training to recognize as food
Not Sole Diet: Best as supplement, not primary food
Mix 1 part powder to 2-3 parts boiling water
Stir vigorously until smooth
Pour into shallow dish, refrigerate until set (2-3 hours)
Cut into small cubes (1cm per cube)
Store in refrigerator 1-2 weeks or freeze 3+ months

content.text: These foods provide variety but should NOT be staples (10-20% of diet maximum).

items: Waxworms: High fat—treat only (1-2 per week). Good for underweight axolotls.
Hornworms: Moderate protein, hydrating—occasional variety (2-3 per week).
Crickets: Gut-loaded, dusted with calcium—occasional (3-4 per feeding, once weekly). Remove legs/head before feeding (choking hazard).
Bloodworms (Frozen): Small, convenient—good for juveniles but less nutritious than blackworms.
Brine Shrimp (Frozen): Tiny, low nutrition—okay for juveniles as snack, not meal.

content.text: Occasional foods should NOT exceed 20% of total diet. Overfeeding high-fat foods (waxworms) causes obesity and fatty liver disease.

rows: Hard exoskeleton difficult to digest, impaction risk
High thiaminase (vitamin B1 deficiency), parasites, fatty
Harbor parasites, poor water quality from supplier tanks
Wrong fat/protein ratio, no nutritional balance
Designed for fish, not amphibians—nutritional mismatch
Repashy Grub Pie or whole prey
Nip axolotl gills, stress, potential disease transmission
Keep axolotls solitary, feed frozen fish
No nutritional value, causes digestive blockage
Disease vectors, high thiaminase, poor nutrition

content.text: NEVER feed live fish to axolotls. Fish nip gills, transmit parasites, and have poor nutritional value. Frozen fish are safer and more nutritious.

items: Use long feeding tongs or chopsticks
Hold food 1-2 inches from axolotl's head
Wiggle food to trigger feeding response
Axolotl will snap/suck food from tongs
Advantages: Prevents substrate ingestion, ensures all axolotls in multi-specimen tanks eat, interactive feeding
Drop food near axolotl (not directly on head)
Works well for wriggling worms—movement triggers feeding
Disadvantages: Food may land on substrate, axolotl inhales substrate while eating
Monitor to ensure food is consumed—remove uneaten food
Shallow dish (ceramic, glass) on tank bottom
Place food in dish, axolotl learns to check dish at feeding time
Advantages: Easy to remove uneaten food, reduces substrate ingestion
Disadvantages: Less interactive, some axolotls ignore dish initially (training period)

content.text: Determining correct portion sizes prevents underfeeding (stunted growth) and overfeeding (obesity).

items: Juveniles: As much as they'll eat in 10-15 minutes, once daily
Adults: Abdomen should be slightly rounded after meal, not bulging
Earthworm Portions: Adult axolotl (10 inches) = 3-4 large nightcrawlers every 2-3 days
Visual Check: Axolotl should have visible backbone when hungry (not spine protruding), slightly filled when fed
Visibly swollen abdomen lasting 24+ hours after feeding
Floating (intestinal gas from overfeeding)
Regurgitating food 1-2 hours after eating
Rapid nitrate accumulation in tank (excess waste)
Loss of visible spine/waistline—looks rounded/tubby even when unfed
Prominent spine and hip bones visible even after feeding
Thin appearance—head wider than body
Frantic feeding behavior—lunges desperately at food
Slow growth rate in juveniles (should grow 1-2 inches per month)
Lethargy from insufficient energy

content.text: When switching from daily to every-other-day feeding (around 6 inches length), increase portion size by 50% to compensate for reduced frequency. Monitor body condition and adjust accordingly.

items: Adult axolotls can safely fast 1-2 weeks without harm
Fasting recommended during water quality emergencies (reduces ammonia production)
Some keepers fast adults 1 day per week to prevent obesity
Never fast juveniles—they need consistent food for growth
After illness/medication, resume feeding at 50% normal portions
Gradually increase to full portions over 5-7 days
Offer highly palatable foods (blackworms, small earthworms) to encourage appetite
If axolotl refuses food 5+ days post-recovery, consult exotic vet
Use feeding tongs to ensure each axolotl receives appropriate portion
Feed in separate corners to prevent competition/aggression
Watch for dominant axolotl stealing food from smaller tank mates
Consider temporary separation during feeding if aggression occurs
Remove uneaten food after 30 minutes to prevent water quality issues

content.text: Feeding directly impacts water quality. Overfeeding is a leading cause of ammonia spikes.

items: Always Remove Uneaten Food: After 30 minutes, siphon out uneaten worms/fish to prevent decomposition
Reduce Feeding if Nitrates Rise: If nitrates climb rapidly (10+ ppm per week), reduce portion size or frequency
Fast During Water Emergencies: If ammonia/nitrites detected, stop feeding until parameters stabilize (0 ppm for 48+ hours)
Post-Water Change Feeding: Some keepers skip feeding day of water change to avoid excess waste accumulation
Buy earthworms in bulk online (500-1000 count)—significant per-worm savings
Maintain DIY worm composting bin—worms reproduce, free food long-term
Alternate between earthworms (cheap) and occasional variety foods (expensive) instead of all premium foods
Purchase frozen fish in bulk bags instead of small packets
Split bulk orders with other axolotl keepers—group buying discounts

rows: Obesity, fatty liver disease, reduced lifespan
Rotate 2-3 staple foods (earthworms, blackworms, frozen fish)
Parasites, disease, gill damage, poor nutrition
Feed frozen fish only—safer, more nutritious
Cut food to 1/2 axolotl's head width maximum
Stress from handling, some keepers report reduced appetite
Feed 2-3 hours after water change or skip that day
Continued ammonia production worsens water quality

items: Immediate interest when food presented—turns toward food, approaches
Powerful suction feeding—food disappears instantly
Swallows food within 5-10 seconds
Resumes normal activity after feeding (no floating, no regurgitation)
Consistent appetite on feeding schedule
Gradual, steady growth in juveniles (1-2 inches per month)
Healthy body condition—slight spine visibility when unfed, slight fill when fed

content.text: If axolotl refuses food for 3+ consecutive feedings:

items: Test Water: Ammonia, nitrites, nitrates, pH, temperature—poor water quality = appetite loss
Check Temperature: Above 70°F reduces appetite. Cool water immediately.
Offer Different Food: Switch from earthworms to blackworms or frozen fish—may stimulate interest
Check for Illness: Curled gills, fungus, lethargy indicate health issues—consult exotic vet
Reduce Stress: Minimize handling, provide hiding spots, reduce light exposure
Fast 3-5 Days: Sometimes appetites reset after brief fasting period (adults only)
Veterinary Consultation: If appetite loss exceeds 7-10 days with no obvious cause
Enrichment & Welfare Guide - Complete overview of axolotl care
Temperature & Water Quality Guide - Water parameters and feeding's impact on water quality
Substrate Guide - Preventing substrate ingestion during feeding
Juveniles (under 8 inches): feed daily. Adults (8+ inches): feed every 2-3 days.
Earthworms are BEST staple food—complete nutrition, appropriate size, readily available
Rotate 2-3 staple foods for balanced nutrition—earthworms, blackworms, frozen silversides
NEVER feed live fish, mealworms, or human food—causes disease, poor nutrition, blockage
All food must be swallowable whole—cut oversized pieces before feeding
Remove uneaten food after 30 minutes—prevents water quality degradation
Tong-feeding preferred—reduces substrate ingestion, ensures even feeding in multi-specimen tanks
Monitor body condition: slight spine visibility when hungry = healthy weight
Fast during water quality emergencies—reduces ammonia production
Monthly feeding cost: $4-30 depending on food choices and bulk buying
